results.title: Norway Kills Freya, a 1,300-Pound Walrus Who Delighted Onlookers
results.abstract: Officials said the walrus had become a threat to human safety because people ignored warnings and did not keep their distance from her in the water.

media.caption: Freya the walrus climbing into a boat in Frognerkilen in Oslo last month. Officials said onlookers had ignored warnings to keep their distance from her.

results.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Maggie Haberman
results.title: Trump’s Shifting Explanations Follow a Familiar Playbook
results.abstract: The former president and his allies have given often conflicting defenses of his retention of classified documents, without addressing why he had kept them.

media.caption: Former President Donald J. Trump and his aides have given inconsistent statements regarding the classified materials removed from his residence in Palm Beach, Fla.

results.byline: By Hurubie Meko and Lauren D’Avolio
results.title: Rushdie Stabbed Roughly 10 Times in Premeditated Attack, Prosecutors Say
results.abstract: The writer, who was gravely wounded and had been put on a ventilator after surgery, is now talking in the hospital, according to his agent.

media.caption: Hadi Matar, 24, center, made an appearance at the Chautauqua County Courthouse in Mayville, N.Y., for his arraignment on charges of second-degree attempted murder and assault with a weapon.

results.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
results.title: A Victory for Biden, and a Bet on America’s Future
results.abstract: Congress gave final approval to the Inflation Reduction Act, which will lower the cost of prescription drugs, extend health care subsidies and invest billions into climate and energy programs.

results.adx_keywords: your-feed-science;your-feed-health;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Coronavirus Omicron Variant;Tests (Medical);Research;Food and Drug Administration
results.title: People Exposed to Coronavirus May Need to Take as Many as Three At-Home Tests, F.D.A. Says
results.abstract: Repeat tests, spaced two days apart, reduce the odds of false negative results, the agency noted.

media.caption: The new F.D.A. recommendations emphasize the need for “additional testing over a longer period of time,” the agency said on Thursday.
media.copyright: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: United States Politics and Government;Classified Information and State Secrets;Law and Legislation;Search and Seizure;Federal Bureau of Investigation;Republican Party;House of Representatives;House Committee on Intelligence
results.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Michael C. Bender
results.title: As Search Shows Trump Had Secret Files, G.O.P. Splits Over Assailing F.B.I.
results.abstract: House Republicans on the Intelligence Committee expressed support for law enforcement. As for lawmakers saying otherwise? “Question them, not us.”

media.caption: Republican members of the House Intelligence Committee discussed the F.B.I. search of former President Donald J. Trump’s home. From left, Brian Fitzpatrick of Pennsylvania, Chris Stewart of Utah, Markwayne Mullin of Oklahoma, Elise Stefanik of New York and Brad Wenstrup of Ohio.
media.copyright: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times

results.title: What the New C.D.C. Guidelines Mean for You
results.abstract: The new recommendations put the onus on individuals to protect themselves. Here’s how to navigate them.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media.caption: If you test positive but have no symptoms — or your symptoms are improving and you have been fever-free for at least a day — you can leave isolation after five days, according to updated C.D.C. guidelines.
media.copyright: Christopher Smith for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Whistle-Blowers;Content Type: Personal Profile;Sex Crimes;Women and Girls;Jogye Order;South Korea;Japan
results.title: Japanese Photographer Blows Whistle on Treatment of ‘Comfort Women’
results.abstract: While Tsukasa Yajima has won praise for exposing problems at South Korea’s best-known shelter for former sex slaves, he has also been the focus of intense backlash.

media.caption: The Japanese photographer Tsukasa Yajima standing in front of portraits he took of former sex slaves at a nursing facility and museum in Gwangju, South Korea, where four of the women live.
media.copyright: Woohae Cho for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Defense and Military Forces;Russia;Ukraine;Crimea (Ukraine);Dnipro (Ukraine);Kherson (Ukraine)
results.byline: By Marc Santora, Michael Schwirtz and Jack Nicas
results.title: With New Weaponry, Ukraine Is Subtly Shifting Its War Strategy
results.abstract: Striking deep behind enemy lines, the Ukrainians are depleting Russia’s combat potential, slowing its advance in the east and creating new vulnerabilities in the south.

media.caption: Smoke rising after a strike on a Russian military base near Novofedorivka, in Crimea, on Tuesday. Ukraine is exploiting its new capacity to strike deep behind enemy lines to deplete Russia’s combat potential.

results.adx_keywords: Classified Information and State Secrets;United States Politics and Government;Trump, Donald J;Federal Bureau of Investigation;Justice Department;Mar-a-Lago (Palm Beach, Fla);National Archives and Records Administration
results.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush
results.title: Trump Lawyer Told Justice Dept. That Classified Material Had Been Returned
results.abstract: The lawyer signed a statement in June that all documents marked as classified and held in boxes in storage at Mar-a-Lago had been given back. The search at the former president’s home on Monday turned up more.

media.caption: An inventory of the material taken from Mar-a-Lago on Monday showed that F.B.I. agents seized 11 sets of documents with some type of confidential or secret marking on them.

results.abstract: Fears about TikTok and rumors of a secret documentary swirl around sorority rush week at the University of Alabama.

results.title: Salman Rushdie, Badly Wounded, Is Off Ventilator and Starting to Recover
results.abstract: Mr. Rushdie’s agent said Sunday that the writer, who was attacked on Friday after years under threat, was beginning a slow journey of healing.

results.title: Silver-Haired and Shameless About Perks: Retirees Take Part-Time Work in the Travel Industry
results.abstract: Spend 15 hours a week loading baggage at the airport or passing out towels at the pool, and you can see Europe for a fraction of the usual cost.

media.caption: Joey Boyd-Scott, left, and her wife, Maria, both have part-time travel jobs. The ongoing labor shortage is pushing the sector to consider senior citizens for positions that are far from senior.
media.copyright: Beth Coller for The New York Times
